text: this is david sanger of the New York
Times there's not a lot of debate that
when Barack Obama is inaugurated as the
44th President of the United States he's
going to face a range of problems around
the world that are probably as complex
as any since Franklin Roosevelt took
office in 1933 but mr. Obama is going to
be inheriting more than just problems
he's also going to be inheriting a
series of covert programs that president
bush is going to hand off to him
programs that to some are reminiscent of
many of the problems that Jack Kennedy
faced in 1961 it was Kennedy you'll
remember who executed in the first few
months of his presidency the Bay of Pigs
an operation to topple Castro that fell
apart it had been the invention of the
Eisenhower administration it simply
didn't work and Kennedy said later that
he wasn't quite sure how well his
administration had understood its
implications president-elect obama's
aides are highly aware of this history
and they're highly aware of these risks
as i discovered last year when i took
most of the year off to work on a book
called the inheritance the world Obama
confronts and the challenges to American
power this time of course the problem is
in Cuba anymore it states like Iran and
Pakistan where the United States has
major operations underway that President
Obama is going to have to make some big
decisions about and those decisions go
to whether or not he continues the
programs kills them or modifies them in
some way that he's more comfortable with
Iran is a good place to start last year
the Israelis came to the Bush
administration secretly and ask them for
a number of things that they would need
in order to be able to strike the
nuclear complex at Natanz which is the
centerpiece of the Iranian nuclear
program they asked for bunker-busting
bombs they asked for refueling equipment
and they asked for the right to overfly
iraq
to shorten the trip to Iran it was never
clear to the White House whether or not
the Israelis actually plan to have an
attack or whether they were simply
trying to spook Americans into taking
stronger action but President Bush
responded that it was not necessary to
conduct that kind of bombing operation
he said that he had authorized a number
of other covert actions that he hoped
overtime would slow the pathway to a
bomb for the Iranians these actions are
mostly focused against the main complex
at Natanz but also add a number of other
suspected Iranian facilities and most of
them are intended to try to interfere
with the way the Iranians get their
supplies for their nuclear program or to
disrupt existing operations including
the centrifuges that are used to enrich
uranium there's no evidence that any of
these programs have worked yet but it
may be too early for president-elect
Obama it's a particularly difficult
issue though because he has promised to
have direct talks with the Iranians and
it raises the question of how you
interact with the country at the same
time that you are participating in
efforts sponsored by many different
countries to slow their nuclear progress
it's one of the many thorny covert
problems that president-elect Obama is
going to have to decide on in the
opening months of his presidency
Pakistan poses a very different kind of
problem there we the United States has
worked cooperatively with the Pakistani
government on a hundred-million-dollar
program to help secure Pakistan's
nuclear arsenal the fear of course is
that insurgents al Qaeda Taliban others
who are seeking to destabilize the
Pakistani government might one day get a
hold of one of Pakistan's nuclear
weapons or the technology that's in its
laboratories but in this case the
program has an additional complexity the
Pakistanis simply don't trust us they
believe that if their government was
vulnerable the United States might be
planning to seize their nuclear
arsenal with US forces so they have not
allowed the u.s. to come in and see what
the American sponsored program has
accomplished instead they simply report
back and say that everything is fine the
difficulty this poses for the u.s. is we
don't really have much of a window into
the Pakistani program and that's
worrisome particularly because of a
stream of US intelligence that
Pakistanis were being trained abroad may
be trying to reintegrate themselves back
into the Pakistani nuclear program and
that some of them may have jihadist
sympathies in Pakistan there's another
program underway as well those are
secret raids that are run from
Afghanistan into Pakistan in order to
hunt down al Qaeda and other insurgents
President Bush issued orders last summer
that greatly expanded this program and a
lot of American special forces for the
first time to go after insurgents who
are not members of al Qaeda we saw once
I trade in September the Pakistani
government immediately protested that
the American action was a violation of
their sovereignty and they're very
concerned that their government not
appear to be a lap dog to the Americans
and so once again another major covert
program that President Bush is leaving
to president-elect Obama will have to be
reviewed and perhaps significantly
modified these are the real kinds of
decisions that presidents have to make
when they come into office there's
nothing in the textbooks nothing in the
civics courses about making these kinds
of trade-offs it's something that
president-elect obama will be new to his
team of advisors will be more
experienced in this area but we still
don't know what kind of decisions what
kind of trade-offs the president-elect
is now willing to make this is david
sanger for the new york times
you
